Dear Ms. Taylor:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager Jessica VandenHeuvel at (616) 204-6992.
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

Sincerely,
Jennifer Pastorick, Licensing Consultant

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Incident reporting
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4150
Section (3) If an institution determines that a youth is absent without legal
Description permission, then the institution shall immediately report the
information to law enforcement, the parent/legal guardian or next
of kin, the licensing authority, and the referring agency.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
2

Allegation One youth went AWOLP (absent without legal permission) this
weekend around midnight and no notifications were made until
6am.
Investigation Interviews:
Education Provider 1 was interviewed via telephone on
11/13/2024. Education Provider 1 reported youth routinely
AWOLP (absent without legal permission) from the facility.
Education Provider 1 did not know names of the alleged youth
who went AWOLP around midnight nor did Education Provider 1
know when this occurred. Education Provider 1 did not have any
information regarding if required notifications were made.
Education Provider 2 was interviewed via telephone on
11/18/2024. Education Provider 2 reported overhearing staff,
unable to recall who, talking about Youth A going AWOLP from
the facility. Education Provider 2 reported he did not know when
Youth A went AWOLP and did not have any information regarding
if notifications were made or not.
Youth A was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
11/19/2024. Youth A reported she went AWOLP from the facility
however never with a male youth or in the last few months around
midnight.
Education Provider 3 was interview via telephone on
11/27/2024. Education Provider 3 reported Youth A went AWOL
11/9/2024 evening into the morning of 11/10/2024. Education
Provider 3 reported she was called to come to the facility on the
morning of 11/10/2024 due to Youth A breaking into Camp 3 with
a male youth from Clarence Fischer Center where the school
personnel’s offices are located. Youth A locked herself in the
secretary’s office and staff at the facility did not have a key to
open the door and needed Education Provider 3’s key. Education
Provider 3 reported she arrived at the facility and was informed by
Director of Operations that she was not alerted until 6am of Youth
A being AWOLP. Education Provider 3 reported no staff knew
where Youth A was throughout the night.
Administrator 1 was interviewed via telephone on 12/11/2024
and 12/13/2024. Administrator 1 reported Youth A went AWOLP
the weekend of 11/9/2024-11/10/2024. Administrator 1 reported
Youth A and a male youth were found making waffles in Camp 3.
Administrator 1 reported she made notifications of the AWOLP to
the Facilities Licensing Consultant and the referring agency.
Administrator 1 reported she notified the Facilities Licensing
Consultant at 2:48am via email. Administrator 1 reported she
3

notified the referring agency however did not recall if it was
through email or phone. Upon receiving the worker notification,
Administrator 1 was reinterviewed regarding the time difference
between the Facilities Assigned Consultant being notified and the
referring agency. Administrator 1 reported she was aware of the
required notifications however had only been with the agency for a
month and was unaware at that time whose responsibility it was to
make the required notifications.
Documents Reviewed:
• Wolverine Human Services Critical Incident Response and
Reporting- Residential Programs Risk Prevention Management
Policy: Critical Incidents include AWOLP. The following entities
need to be notified as soon as possible within 24 hours of
the incident if it is considered critical - Referring
Worker/Court Liaison and Department of Child Welfare
Licensing.
• Behavior Notification dated 11/9/2024 at 9:26pm for Youth
A: Youth A ran for an unknown reason at 9:26pm. Action
taken: Staff looked for Youth A from 10pm until 7am on
11/10/2024.
• Email dated 11/10/2024 at 2:48am from Administrator 1 to
Facilities Licensing Consultant: Youth A is AWOLP, staff
are still looking for her and police have been contacted.
• Screen shot of Administrator 1’s phone call to Youth A’s
worker was sent to consultant showing the referring worker
was called on 11/10/2024 at 7:17am.
• Email dated 1/12/2025 from Chief Administrator
documented a social work contact entered in the facilities
system showing Youth A’s mother was contacted on
11/10/2024 however it is unknown what time. The contact
documents Youth A left the facility and staff lost line of
signed around 9:30pm on 11/9/2024.
Analysis The facility is found in noncompliance as notifications shall be
made immediately to law enforcement, the parent/legal guardian
or next of kin, the licensing authority, and the referring agency.
Youth A went AWOLP on 11/9/2024 per the behavior notification
at 9:26pm. The facilities assigned consultant was notified via
email at 2:48am, law enforcement had been contacted at 9:56pm
and notification was made to the referring agency at 7:17am.
Youth A’s mother was notified on 11/10/2024 however it is unclear
what time.
4

Conclusion Repeat Violation Established

Rule Code Facility and premises maintenance
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4407
Section (1) A facility and premises shall be maintained in a clean,
Description comfortable, and safe condition. The facility shall be located on
land that is properly drained.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Multiple windows are broken of buildings and glass in on the
ground not cleaned up.
Investigation It should be noted Camp 3 is not a building that is licensed by the
Division of Child Welfare Licensing.
Interviews:
Education Provider 2 was interviewed via telephone on
11/18/2024. Education Provider 2 reported youth break windows
on the campus all the time. Education Provider 2 reported youth
attempted to break into Camp 3 building and the glass was not
cleaned up for two days. Education Provider 2 reported the glass
was cleaned up by Wolverine Human Services staff. Education
Provider 2 reported youth from the facility would not have had
access to the glass unless youth would have broken into Camp 3.
Education Provider 2 reported windows have been broken at
Vassar House and times vary from an hour or longer depending
on what staff are available to clean up the glass or if it occurs over
the weekend. Education Provider 2 was unaware of any youth
obtaining glass from broken windows.
Education Provider 3 was interview via telephone on
11/27/2024. Education Provider 3 reported in Camp 3 there was a
broken window on 9/3/2024. Education Provider 3 reported she
notified Director of Operations about the broken window and left
the glass to see how long it would take for the facility to clean it
up. Education Provider 3 reported it took three to four days for the
glass to be cleaned up. Education Provider 3 reported youth are
not supposed to be in Camp 3 unless they are testing for their
GED however youth have broken into Camp 3. Education
Provider 3 reported youth break windows at the facility all the time
and maintenance do the best they can do on cleaning up the glass
and repairing the windows. Education Provider 3 reported she has
not seen any broken glass laying on the ground at Vassar House
and the facility tries to clean it up right away.
5

Staff 2 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
11/19/2024. Staff 2 reported there have been no windows broken
at the facility while Staff 2 has been working. Staff 2 reported
maintenance usually addresses broken windows and cleaning up
the glass at the facility.
Staff 3 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
11/19/2024. Staff 3 reported no windows at the facility have been
broken during her shifts. Staff 3 reported if a window is broken at
the facility, the window is boarded up and glass is cleaned up.
Staff 3 reported she has never seen broken glass around the
facility.
Staff 4 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
11/19/2024. Staff 4 reported she has not been working at the
facility when any windows were broken.
Supervisor was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
11/19/2024. Supervisor reported Vassar House has one boarded
window due to Youth A breaking the window recently. Supervisor
reported no knowledge of seeing glass on the ground around
Vassar House.
Youth A was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
11/19/2024. Youth A reported she broke a window at the facility
last week. Youth A reported staff cleaned up the broken glass
within ten minutes. Youth A reported she has never seen broken
glass laying around at the facility.
Maintenance was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
11/19/2024. Maintenance reported he was called to the facility
last week around 12:30/1am for a broken window. Maintenance
reported he was contacted immediately and went to the facility to
board up the broken window and assist with cleaning up the glass.
Maintenance is on call 24/7 to assist when windows and items are
broken at the facility. Maintenance reported glass from broken
windows is cleaned up immediately by staff at the facility.
Director of Operations was interviewed via telephone on
11/20/2024. Director of Operations reported when windows are
broken at the facility the glass is cleaned up immediately by staff
and/or maintenance depending on who is there. Maintenance
boards up the window while a new window is ordered if the facility
does not have the window as an extra onsite. Director of
6

Operations reported no knowledges of any broken glass not being
immediately cleaned up at Vassar House.
Administrator 1 was interviewed via telephone on 12/11/2024.
Administrator 1 reported no knowledge of glass not being cleaned
up at the facility. Administrator 1 reported never seeing any glass
laying around the facility. Administrator 1 reported youth should
not be in Camp 3 at any time.
Administrator 2 was interviewed via telephone on 12/11/2024.
Administrator 2 reported when a window is broken at the facility
the maintenance team comes to clean up the glass and board up
the window until a new window is available to install.
Administrator 2 has not seen any glass laying around the facility.
Administrator 2 reported only school officials are to be in Camp 3
as they have offices located in that building however youth are not
to be in Camp 3.
Tour Observation:
A tour of the outside and inside Vassar House occurred on
11/19/2024 and 12/10/2024. On 11/19/2024 there was one
window that was boarded up due to recently being broken. There
was one pebble size piece of glass found near the window that
had been broken however no other glass was observed on the
ground around Vassar House.
Documents Reviewed:
• Email from Administrator 2 to consultant dated 12/3/2024:
No youth are pursuing GED’s and have not in quite some
time. Administrator 2 is not aware of any spring testing or
candy passing occurring at Camp 3 and will address this.
• Email from Administrator 2 to Educational Provider 2 dated
12/3/2024: youth should not be going to Camp 3 for
anything.
Analysis The facility is found in compliance as per interviews and tour of
the facility, staff clean up broken glass when it occurs. Per
interviews the broken glass was at Camp 3 which is not a licensed
building and youth are not supposed to be in the building.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code Means of egress
Title
7

Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4538
Section (1) Means of egress shall be considered the entire way and
Description method of passage to free and safe ground outside a facility. All
required means of egress shall be maintained in an unobstructed,
easily traveled condition at all times.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth broke into “Camp 3” so Wolverine screwed the doors shut.
Investigation It should be noted Camp 3 is not a building that is licensed by the
Division of Child Welfare Licensing.
Interviews:
Education Provider 1 was interviewed via telephone on
11/13/2024. Education Provider 1 reported Camp 3 is the building
where the educational providers are housed at the facility.
Education Provider 1 reported six of nine doors at the building are
screwed shut due to youth breaking into the building.
Education Provider 2 was interviewed via telephone on
11/18/2024. Education Provider 2 reported school offices are in
Camp 3. Education Provider 2 reported youth at the facility attend
classes daily in the classrooms in Clarence Fischer Center.
Education Provider 2 reported the only time youth go into Camp 3
for school activities would be if a youth needs to take a GED test,
to be given candy as a reward for positive behavior, or for spring
testing. Education Provider 2 reported youth rarely go into Camp
3.
Education Provider 3 was interview via telephone on
11/27/2024. Education Provider 3 reported after youth broke into
Camp 3 on 11/9/2024-11/10/2024 the doors were screwed closed
due to the youth breaking the doors. Education Provider 3
reported some of the doors have since been fixed and are no
longer screwed closed however one or two doors remain bolted
closed. The one to two doors that remain bolted closed are in the
front section of Camp 3 where Education Provider 3 reported she
does not have access to.
Youth A was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
11/19/2024. Youth A reported the life skills room has not been
used by youth in month and currently is bolted closed due to youth
breaking into the room. Youth A reported no other doors are
bolted closed at the facility.
Maintenance was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
11/19/2024. Maintenance reported youth broke into the life skills
8

room and broke the handle on the door. Maintenance reported
the door was bolted closed to secure the door while the facility
waits for the new door handle parts to arrive as the facility had to
order the parts. Maintenance reported there are no other doors at
the facility bolted closed. Maintenance reported Camp 3 is not a
licensed building at the facility. Maintenance reported the medical
building on the facility grounds is used by nursing staff and
administration. The medical building does have locks on the
windows and some doors are bolted closed due to youth
attempting to break into the building.
Supervisor was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
11/19/2024. Supervisor reported the life skills room has not been
utilized in a few months and currently cleaning supplies are stored
in there.
Director of Operations was interviewed via telephone on
11/20/2024. Director of Operations reported one week ago youth
broke into the area that has been utilized previously as the life
skills room where now cleaning supplies are stored. The door has
been screwed shut to secure the door while the pieces are on
order for the door to be fixed. The front door to the life skills room
is functioning properly.
Administrator 1 was interviewed via telephone on 12/11/2024.
Administrator 1 reported she heard about the door on the life skills
room however has not seen it.
Administrator 2 was interviewed via telephone on 12/11/2024.
Administrator 2 reported the only door bolted closed at Vassar
House is the back door of the life skills room and that is due to
youth breaking the door and the door needing a new part to
remain closed. The facility has ordered the part and is waiting for
the part to arrive. Administrator 2 reported the door is a door that
exits from a closet in the life skills room. Administrator reported
the life skills room is not in use and provided an agency response
plan indicating the life skills room would not be used until the door
is fixed.
Tour Observation:
A tour of the facility occurred on 11/19/2024 and 12/10/2024. The
only door that is bolted closed is the door leading out the side of
the life skills room.
Documents Reviewed:
9

• Agency Response Plan received by the agency 12/3/2024:
The life skills room is temporarily closed due to a door
maintenance issue and is not to be used by staff or youth
until notification has been received that the life skills room
is ready to reopen.
• Advanced Home and Door Solution Estimate dated
11/12/2024 verifying the facility ordered the parts to fix the
life skills room door and the estimated delivery date
indicated 12/19/2024.
Analysis The facility is found in compliance as there is one door at Vassar
House that is bolted closed which is the life skills room back door.
The life skills room door was broken by youth breaking into the
room and is bolted closed as the facility had to order the
replacement part to repair the door. The facility completed an
agency response plan, and the life skills room is not to be used
until the door is fixed.
Per interviews doors are bolted closed at Camp 3 as youth have
broken into Camp 3. Youth are not supposed to be at Camp 3.
Camp 3 is not a licensed building at the facility and is used for
storage and personnel offices.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code Fire extinguishers
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4532
Section (4) All fire extinguishers shall be located not less than 4 inches off
Description the floor and the top of the extinguisher shall not be higher than 5
feet off the floor in a special cabinet or on a wall rack which is
easily accessible at all times, unless programmatically
contraindicated. Where programmatically contraindicated, the
required extinguishers may be kept behind locked doors if both of
the following conditions are met:
(b) All staff carry keys to the doors.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Fire extinguishers are locked in the office and not everyone has
access to the locked area.
Investigation It should be noted Camp 3 is not a building that is licensed by the
Division of Child Welfare Licensing.
Interviews:
Education Provider 1 was interviewed via telephone on
11/13/2024. Education Provider 1 reported no fire extinguishers
10

being present in Camp 3. Education Provider 1 inquired with
Administrative Coordinator about location of fire extinguishers in
Camp 3 and was informed they are in the office. Education
Provider 1 reported not everyone has keys to access the office
areas.
Education Provider 2 was interviewed face-to-face on
11/19/2024. Education Provider 2 reported he does have keys to
the office areas in Vassar House and has the A key which
Education Provider 2 verified worked on the classroom doors and
main office doors. Education Provider 2 verified two out of three
of the classrooms had fire extinguishers.
Education Provider 3 was interview via telephone on
11/27/2024. Education Provider 3 reported fire extinguishers have
been used by the youth as weapons at the facility. Education
Provider 3 reported in Vassar House there are some fire
extinguishers on the wall and there is a fire extinguisher in
classroom 2. Education Provider 3 reported she did not know if
there are any fire extinguishers on the pods as she does not go
onto the pods. Education Provider 3 reported she does not have
a key to get into some locked areas at the facility and did not know
if all facility staff had keys to get into all locked areas.
Staff 2 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
11/19/2024. Staff 2 reported he did not have keys at the facility
for approximately the first sixty days when first hired. Staff 2
reported he would have to text or call the on-shift supervisor or
ask the second staff assigned to the pod to open doors for him.
Staff 3 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
11/19/2024. Staff 3 reported if staff do not have keys at the facility
the shift supervisor opens doors for the staff and youth. Staff 3
reported all staff are given keys to the facility when they start
working however, she has forgotten her keys at home
occasionally which makes it difficult to get into places as she has
to rely on other staff to open doors for her.
Staff 4 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
11/19/2024. Staff 4 reported when she started at the facility it took
a little time to get keys assigned to her however, she did not recall
how long. Staff 4 reported she forgot her keys at home today
however there is a second staff assigned on her pod with keys, so
she is able to get into locked areas with the other staff’s keys.
11

Administrative Coordinator was interviewed face-to-face at
the facility on 11/19/2024. Administrative Coordinator reported
she was just informed during a meeting this morning about fire
extinguishers. Administrative Coordinator reported she was aware
that youth recently set off some of the fire extinguishers at the
facility and Director of Operations is the individual that addresses
the fire extinguishers.
Director of Operations was interviewed via telephone on
11/20/2024. Director of Operations reported youth at the facility
broke the fire extinguisher boxes and used the fire extinguishers
to shoot at other youth, staff, and were threatening to hit staff with
the fire extinguishers. Director of Operations reported fire
extinguishers are in each case managers office on each of the
units. There are three classrooms and two of the classrooms
have fire extinguishers in the closet of the classroom where the
furnace is located. The one classroom that currently does not
have an extinguisher is due to the extinguisher being sprayed by a
youth last week and the extinguisher was sent out to be refilled.
There is one wet and two dry fire extinguishers in the kitchen
which covers the dining room area as well. Director of Operations
reported all staff have keys to be able to access the locations of
the fire extinguishers. Director of Operations reported to her
knowledge there are no issues with staff being issued keys when
they start working at the facility however Human Resources
provides keys to staff once staff have completed all their training
and shadowing hours. Director of Operations reported if a staff
lost or broke their key(s) then staff are to request new keys on the
SharePoint site the facility utilizes, and Director of Operations
team will make new keys.
Human Resources was interviewed via telephone on
12/11/2024. Human Resources reported the facility changed the
process of providing staff with keys about two weeks ago. Human
Resources reported previously staff were assigned keys to the
facility after completing orientation and Human Resources
reported no knowledge of any staff not being provided keys at that
time or a lapse in keys being assigned. Human Resources
reported the facility began a process about two weeks ago where
keys are kept in the supervisor’s office and when staff arrive for
their shift, the staff checks in with the supervisor and the
supervisor provides the keys for the shift. At the end of the shift,
staff check out with the supervisor and return the keys. Human
Resources reported all staff have keys to access fire extinguishers
at the facility.
12

Administrator 1 was interviewed via telephone on 12/11/2024.
Administrator 1 reported all staff should have keys to access fire
extinguishers at the facility. Administrator 1 reported prior to her
starting at the facility there was an issue with youth misusing the
fire extinguishers resulting in fire extinguishers being kept behind
locked doors. Administrator 1 reported the facility just transitioned
from all staff being provided with keys to the facility to keys being
kept in a lock box in the supervisor’s office and at the beginning of
the shift, staff check in with the supervisor and are provided keys
and return the keys at the end of the shift. Administrator 1
reported the staff keys access all areas where the fire
extinguishers are kept.
Administrator 2 was interviewed via telephone on 12/11/2024.
Administrator 2 reported all staff have keys now to access fire
extinguishers in the facility. Administrator 2 reported the facility
just transitioned from all staff being provided with keys to the
facility to keys being kept in a lock box in the supervisor’s office
and at the beginning of the shift, staff check in with the supervisor
and are provided keys and return the keys at the end of the shift.
Tour Observation:
A tour of the facility occurred on 11/19/2024. There was a fire
extinguisher in the hallway outside the classrooms, two of the
three classrooms had a fire extinguisher, there was a fire
extinguisher placed in an office in the office area in the hallway
near the classrooms, and fire extinguishers in the office area on
the pods.
Documents Reviewed:
• Email from Director of Operations dated 12/9/2024
confirming staff have keys to all locations where fire
extinguishers are located in the facility.
Analysis The facility is found in compliance as there are fire extinguishers
located on the pods, in the classrooms, in the fire extinguisher box
in the hallway outside the school, and in the offices in the school
hallway in Vassar House. Fire extinguisher were not all locked
behind closed doors and were in access to staff if needed.
Some of the locations of the fire extinguishers did require keys to
access such as in the office area however in the school hallway
there was a fire extinguisher that was able to be accessed by all
staff. Per staff interviews, it appears there was difficulty with staff
being assigned keys once they completed orientation as well as
when staff forget their keys at home and as a result staff rely on
13

other staff and supervisors to open doors for them and the youth.
Per the facilities new process, the facility now has staff check in at
the beginning of their shift and keys are assigned to the staff and
at the end of the shift, the staff checks in with the supervisor and
returns the keys which will address the key issue.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code Education
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4123
Section (1) An institution shall not admit a child for care unless an
Description appropriate educational program can be provided.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth are not attending school.
Investigation Interviews:
Education Provider 2 was interviewed via telephone on
11/18/2024. Education Provider 2 reported maintaining a session
log where youth attendance is documented. Education Provider 2
reported on 11/18/2024 none of the youth showed up to school
until 9:15am as one youth was refusing to go to school and there
was only one staff working in the pod resulting in the whole pod
being unable to attend school. Education Provider 2 reported on
11/18/2024 Staff 1 informed him she was unsure how many youth
he would have in school as there were not enough staff at the
facility. Education Provider 2 reported the youth at the facility have
no consequences for not attending school.
Education Provider 3 was interview via telephone on
11/27/2024. Education Provider 3 reported the youth at Vassar
House are not showing up to school due to the youth going
AWOLP at night and the facility providing the youth with seven
hours of sleep once youth return from AWOLP causing the youth
to miss school. Education Provider 3 reported if the staff to youth
ratio is 1:3, the youth will take turns refusing to go to school
resulting in the other youth not being able to go due to only one
staff working.
Youth A was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
11/19/2024. Youth A reported school is scheduled to start
weekdays at 7:30am. Youth A reported there is no motivation to
go to school. Youth A reported she has refused to go to school
however when she has refused, other youth in the pod still are
able to attend school. Youth A reported she attended school
14

yesterday on 11/18/2024 when Staff 1 was the assigned staff on
her pod. Youth A reported if a youth refuses to go to school and
there is only one staff working on the pod, the supervisor on shift
will come to the pod in order for the other youth to attend school.
Youth A reported youth are never held back from school due to
one youth on the pod refusing to go.
Youth B was interviewed via teams on 12/13/2024. Youth B
reported she attends school every day. Youth B reported there
have not been any times where she has wanted to attend school
and was unable to while at the facility.
Youth C was interviewed via teams on 12/13/2024. Youth C
reported she attends school every day unless she is not feeling
well. Youth C reported there have not been any times where she
wanted to attend school and was unable to while at the facility.
